hints.label: rem-log-k-absorption-mechanism
hints.title: Explicit Mechanism of (log k)^d Absorption
hints.content:
138: :label: rem-log-k-absorption-mechanism
139: 
140: The claim that the $(log k)^d$ factor is "absorbed into Gevrey-1 constants" requires explicit justification.
141: 
142: **Where does (log k)^d appear?**
143: 
144: Only in the $j=i$ term of the localized mean derivative:
145: 
146: $$
147: \nabla^m \mu_\rho^{(i)} = \nabla^m \left(\sum_{j \in \mathcal{A}} w_{ij}(\rho) d_j\right) = \nabla^m(w_{ii} d_i) + \sum_{j \neq i} \nabla^m(w_{ij} d_j)
148: $$
149: 
150: For $j = i$: The measurement $d_i = \mathbb{E}[d_{\text{alg}}(i, c(i))]$ involves a sum over $k_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)} = O((\log k)^d)$ effective companions. By the product and chain rules:
151: 
152: $$
153: \|\nabla^m (w_{ii} d_i)\| \leq C_w \cdot C_d \cdot m! \cdot \rho^{-m} \cdot k_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)}
154: $$
155: 
156: For $j \neq i$: **Derivative locality** (§7.1) eliminates the $\ell$-sum—only $\ell=i$ contributes to $\nabla_{x_i} d_j$, so there's NO $(log k)^d$ factor for these terms.
157: 
158: **How is (log k)^d absorbed?**
159: 
160: The Gevrey-1 structure of $C_{V,m}$ is:
161: 
162: $$
163: C_{V,m} = \tilde{C}_m \cdot (1 + c \cdot k_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)} / m!) \cdot \max(\rho^{-m}, \varepsilon_d^{1-m})
164: $$
165: 
166: For $m \geq 2$, the regularization term $\varepsilon_d^{1-m}$ dominates. Since $\varepsilon_d \ll \varepsilon_c$ (typically $\varepsilon_d / \varepsilon_c = 10^{-3}$):
167: 
168: $$
169: \varepsilon_d^{1-m} = \varepsilon_c^{1-m} \cdot (10^{-3})^{1-m} = \varepsilon_c^{1-m} \cdot 10^{3(m-1)}
170: $$
171: 
172: The ratio $(log k)^d / m!$ for practical $k \leq 10^6$ (where $(\log k)^d \leq 20^d$ for $d \leq 20$):
173: 
174: $$
175: \frac{(\log k)^d}{m!} \leq \frac{20^d}{m!}
176: $$
177: 
178: For $m \geq d+2$, the factorial $m!$ dominates exponentially. For example:
179: - $d=10, m=15$: $(log 1000)^{10} / 15! \approx 10^{10} / 10^{12} = 10^{-2}$
180: - $d=20, m=25$: $(log 1000)^{20} / 25! \approx 10^{20} / 10^{25} = 10^{-5}$
181: 
182: **Conclusion**: The $(log k)^d$ factor from the $j=i$ term is sub-leading compared to:
183: 1. The factorial growth $m!$ (Gevrey-1)
184: 2. The regularization blowup $\varepsilon_d^{1-m}$ (bottleneck for $m \geq 2$)

hints.label: def-effective-counts-two-scales
hints.title: Effective Interaction Counts (Two Scales)
hints.content:
194: :label: def-effective-counts-two-scales
195: 
196: **1. Softmax Effective Companions** (scale $\varepsilon_c$):
197: 
198: $$
199: k_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)}(i) := \left|\left\{\ell \in \mathcal{A} : d_{\text{alg}}(i,\ell) \leq R_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)}\right\}\right|
200: $$
201: 
202: where:
203: 
204: $$
205: R_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)} = \varepsilon_c \sqrt{C_{\text{comp}}^2 + 2\log(k^2)}
206: $$
207: 
208: **Scaling**:
209: 
210: $$
211: k_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)}(i) = O(\rho_{\max} \cdot \varepsilon_c^{2d} \cdot (\log k)^d)
212: $$
213: 
214: **Properties**:
215: - Grows logarithmically with $k$
216: - NOT k-uniform
217: - Controls softmax companion sums over $\ell$
218: 
219: **2. Localization Effective Neighbors** (scale $\rho$):
220: 
221: $$
222: k_{\text{eff}}^{(\rho)}(i) := \left|\left\{j \in \mathcal{A} : d_{\text{alg}}(i,j) \leq R_{\text{eff}}^{(\rho)}\right\}\right|
223: $$
224: 
225: where:
226: 
227: $$
228: R_{\text{eff}}^{(\rho)} = C_\rho \cdot \rho
229: $$
230: 
231: for some constant $C_\rho$ independent of $k$.
232: 
233: **Scaling**:
234: 
235: $$
236: k_{\text{eff}}^{(\rho)}(i) = O(\rho_{\max} \cdot \rho^{2d})
237: $$
238: 
239: **Properties**:
240: - Independent of $k$

hints.label: notation-keff-superscripts
hints.title: k_eff Superscript Convention
hints.content:
246: :label: notation-keff-superscripts
247: 
248: When we write "$k_{\text{eff}}$" without superscript, the scale should be clear from context:
249: - If discussing softmax, companion selection, or measurements $d_j$: assume $k_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)}$
250: - If discussing localization weights $w_{ij}$, localized moments $\mu_\rho, \sigma_\rho$: assume $k_{\text{eff}}^{(\rho)}$
251: 
252: For clarity in proofs, **always use superscript notation** $k_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)}$ or $k_{\text{eff}}^{(\rho)}$.
